Notes: The old TOEFL took approximately 3 hours, making it more demanding on endurance; the new version trims it to around 2 hours, making it more accessible and less tiring.
The order of sections in the new TOEFL moves Writing before Speaking, potentially reducing test fatigue when writing responses.
The old test had fixed difficulty; the new test adapts the difficulty level in Reading and Listening based on the test taker's performance mid-test.
Both versions have four main sections, but the new TOEFL reorganizes task types and introduces varied formats within those sections.
In the old TOEFL, there was a fixed 10-minute break after Listening. This is no longer necessary due to shorter test length.

New TOEFL - after January 2026: An updated score scale (1 - 6 in half-point increments). Updated score scale: We're introducing an updated score scale (1 - 6 in half-point increments) that more intuitively aligns with the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR), which guides many global students' English learning journeys.
Notes: Scoring remains on a 0-30 scale per section, but the new test applies Item Response Theory (IRT) to provide more accurate scoring in adaptive sections.
Reading time is drastically reduced due to shorter, task-specific readings rather than long academic passages.

New TOEFL - after January 2026: 3 tasks: Complete the Words, Read in Daily Life, Read an Academic Passage
Notes: Instead of long texts, the new format introduces three distinct task types, allowing for better focus on different reading skills.

New TOEFL - after January 2026: Shorter passages (70-250 words), including real-life texts
Notes: Passages in the old test were long and academic; the new ones vary in length and include real-world texts like social media or forms.
While the old TOEFL used a fixed number of questions, the new one uses an adaptive range depending on the student's performance.
Question order in the old test was linear; the new version's task-specific structure changes sequencing logic.

New TOEFL - after January 2026: Adds scanning, grammar, idioms, contextual guessing
Notes: New reading tasks test a broader range of micro-skills like contextual guessing and non-linear scanning.
The new adaptive model considers question difficulty when scoring, offering a more nuanced proficiency profile.
Listening time is reduced thanks to shorter, structured audio tasks replacing longer lectures.

New TOEFL - after January 2026: 4 tasks: Response, Conversation, Announcement, Academic Talk
Notes: Instead of fixed lectures and convos, the new test uses modular tasks that reflect real-life situations like announcements or short conversations.
New listening passages are shorter and more varied in format, improving engagement and reducing fatigue.
Question categories have been collapsed or restructured to reflect practical understanding rather than rigid types.
Both tests restrict navigation between questions, maintaining consistency.
Scoring in the new TOEFL now factors in both correctness and difficulty of items via IRT.
The speaking section has been cut in half, with just two tasks instead of four, making it quicker and potentially less stressful.
Task types shift from opinion and integration toward foundational (repetition) and practical (interview) formats.
Simulated interviews and repeat-after-me prompts replace academic-style prompts to reflect everyday speaking more closely.

New TOEFL - after January 2026: Adds pacing, pronunciation accuracy, response logic
Notes: Fluency and pacing are now explicitly measured, offering a clearer view of spoken language proficiency.
Rubrics are now tailored to each task's format rather than applying a single, broad rubric across all tasks.
The writing section time is nearly halved, but still measures core writing skills with concise tasks.
Three tasks replace two, with greater diversity: grammar structure, genre-based writing, and discussion contribution.
Word count requirements are relaxed in the new test to focus on clarity and purpose rather than length.
Essays are no longer formal academic arguments only - email etiquette and online communication are now evaluated.
Each writing task is scored using criteria specific to that type of writing, leading to fairer evaluation.

New TOEFL - after January 2026: Still no spellcheck; word count only
Notes: Both tests avoid auto-correction features to maintain integrity of language skill evaluation.
The old TOEFL emphasized academic English exclusively; the new version blends academic and functional communication.
Tasks are now more grounded in real life - emails, announcements, interviews - rather than pure academic simulation.
The new TOEFL explicitly tests basic language mechanics like sentence construction and pronunciation repetition.
Instead of large monolithic passages, content is now chunked into specific task units to improve engagement and flexibility.
